author: By Bryan Pietsch, Azi Paybarah and Mihir Zaveri
title: Missing Fort Drum Soldier Is Found Dead in New Jersey
description: A dispute over a car swap appeared to have played a role in the killing of Cpl. Hayden Allen Harris. A fellow soldier was expected to be charged in connection with his death, the authorities said.
content: Two Fort Drum soldiers’ plans to exchange cars late last week ended with one soldier dead in a remote part of New Jersey and the other arrested and expected to face murder and kidnapping charges, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson and Matt Phillips
title: Stocks are roiled as a fast-spreading virus strain in Britain overshadows the stimulus deal.
description: Financial markets were jolted on Monday after the emergence of a fast-spreading coronavirus variant led to the suspension of some trade and travel with Britain as well as another lockdown in London, a new threat that overshadowed progress in Washington toward a long-awaited economic aid package.
content: Financial markets were jolted on Monday after the emergence of a fast-spreading coronavirus variant led to the suspension of some trade and travel with Britain as well as another lockdown in London, a new threat that overshadowed progress in Washington toward a long-awaited economic aid package.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: This Deal Is Good Enough
description: It should be larger. It should have happened months ago. But an agreement on coronavirus aid is still a welcome dose of good news.
content: The $900 billion pandemic aid package that emerged Sunday from months of on-and-off negotiations between House Democrats and Senate Republicans is a necessary measure that will ease the suffering of millions of Americans. It will help unemployed workers to feed their families and to avoid eviction. It will help small businesses avoid bankruptcy. It will help to keep the trains and buses running in cities across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon and Jenny Gross
title: Kansas City Star Apologizes for Racism in Decades of Reporting
description: The newspaper said it had “disenfranchised, ignored and scorned” generations of Black people. The apology comes after one in September by The Los Angeles Times.
content: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — When Mará Rose Williams, an education reporter for The Kansas City Star, was assigned to cover a local Black Lives Matter protest over the summer, she was struck by the difference between what she said she witnessed and what had been reported in previous days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Taylor Swift Lands Her Second No. 1 Album of the Year With ‘Evermore’
description: The sequel to “Folklore” did not have the commercial impact of its predecessor, due in part to changes in the Billboard rules.
content: Due in part to changes in how album sales are counted, Taylor Swift’s second release of the year, “Evermore,” did not have the commercial impact of her first, although it was more than enough to hit No. 1 again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer
title: A Plan by Eastern States to Cap Tailpipe Emissions Gets Off to a Slow Start
description: Connecticut, Massachusetts, Rhode Island and Washington, D.C., all announced they would join a cap-and-trade program for cars and trucks. But many bigger states have yet to join.
content: WASHINGTON — An ambitious plan by Eastern states for a regional cap-and-trade program to curb greenhouse gas emissions from cars and trucks got off to a slow start Monday after just three states — Connecticut, Massachusetts and Rhode Island — plus Washington, D.C., formally agreed to adopt it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim, Jo Becker and Astead W. Herndon
title: Kelly Loeffler, a Wall Street Senator With a Hardscrabble Pitch
description: The hard right turn of Ms. Loeffler, one of two Republican candidates in Georgia’s pivotal Senate runoff elections, reflects the ideological gymnastics embraced by her party in the Trump era.
content: In the year since Kelly Loeffler was appointed to the Senate, the largely unknown financial executive has crafted a narrative of her life and built a campaign around it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Cook Like Alex Guarnaschelli
description: The chef and television personality’s latest cookbook, “Cook With Me,” features unpretentious recipes.
content: Helpful, funny, personal and typically self-deprecating, the voice of Alex Guarnaschelli, the chef, restaurateur and television cooking personality, is unmistakable throughout her new book, “Cook With Me.” There are many great recipes that should have a place on your table. Something for New Year’s? Go no further than her deviled eggs soaked in borscht (not necessarily homemade) to color them purple with whipped cream — whipped cream! — to fluff the filling. Or broil and flame some provolone for delicious fun (it works). And don’t forget dumplings without wrappers, cauliflower steaks, mixed mushrooms or salmon and kale on a sheet pan, a salad of rescued vegetable tops and mulled white wine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dina Gachman
title: Can We Talk About the Mom in ‘A Christmas Story’?
description: The woman hasn’t had a hot meal in 15 years and she’s always cooped up at home. 2020 is the year to give this character from a classic holiday movie her due.
content: It’s been tough to watch movies in 2020 and not project our frustrations and anxieties onto the screen. Maybe the extravagant wedding sequence in “The Godfather” suddenly felt garish compared to all of this year’s Zoom “I Dos.” Or maybe you put on “Elf” to pass some quarantine time, and the crowded mall scenes launched you into a cold sweat, because everyone is inside and no one is wearing a mask.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Klass, M.D
title: What Pediatricians Say Can’t Wait
description: As we celebrate the rollout of the new Covid-19 vaccines, don’t forget the standard immunizations and other steps to keep children safe.
content: Last May, the American Academy of Pediatrics launched a campaign named #CallYourPediatrician. There were humorous visuals, to-do lists with “call pediatrician” right above “learn 3rd grade math,” informational graphics about safe visits in the time of Covid, and adorable videos (watch the baby panda getting his checkup).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naomi Osaka
title: Naomi Osaka: Athletes, Speak Up
description: We’re affected by bias and racism, just like everyone else. Why shouldn’t we say so?
content: This is an article from Turning Points, a special section that explores what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Senior
title: 95 Percent of Representatives Have a Degree. Look Where That’s Got Us.
description: All these credentials haven’t led to better results.
content: Over the last few decades, Congress has diversified in important ways. It has gotten less white, less male, less straight — all positive developments. But as I was staring at one of the many recent Senate hearings, filled with the usual magisterial blustering and self-important yada yada, it dawned on me that there’s a way that Congress has moved in a wrong direction, and become quite brazenly unrepresentative.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Dec. 21, 2020
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Dec. 21, 2020.
content: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Dec. 21, 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: Who Gets the Vaccine Next?
description: Companies, unions and trade groups are making pitches that their workers should be prioritized.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller, Margot Sanger-Katz and Katherine J. Wu
title: What You Can Do Post-Vaccine, and When
description: Particularly in the early months of vaccination, many activities should wait, experts say — and plan to keep your masks.
content: Vaccines are here, bringing hope of the pandemic’s end. But even when you get your dose, it won’t mean an immediate return to life as you knew it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: Google Denies Antitrust Claims in Early Response to U.S. Lawsuit
description: The company said people use its services because they choose to, not because they lack alternatives.
content: Google said on Monday that it had not used its multibillion-dollar deals with other large tech firms to protect its position as the dominant online search engine, in the company’s first formal rebuttal to the Justice Department’s accusations that those deals violated antitrust laws.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Gutierrez
title: A Brazen Police Shooting Caught on Video Sparks Anger in the Philippines
description: The video shows a police officer shooting a woman and her son after a dispute over a noisemaker. Some activists linked the killings to a culture of violence in which the police are allowed to act with impunity.
content: MANILA — A video of a police officer shooting a woman and her adult son at close range on Sunday has spread rapidly across social media in the Philippines, provoking a wave of outrage directed at the government and a police force that many say acts with impunity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Taylor, Nydia Blas, Celeste Noche, Brian Palmer and Timothy Smith
title: Five Kwanzaa Celebrations Around the Country
description: For many Black Americans, the holiday is a time for bonding, joy and repose. The Times visited five households to see how people cook and gather, engage and reflect.
content: Kwanzaa is more than an end-of-year display of deep orange and burnt burgundy Dutch wax-print fabrics, and righteous images of fruit bowls sitting near wooden cups. It’s an edifying lifestyle choice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: A Winter Solstice, a Meteor Shower, Jupiter and Saturn Walk Into Your Night Sky
description: One day that has room for three distinct astronomical events.
content: While it’s been a terrible year in a lot of ways, 2020 has had some impressive astronomical occurrences. Remember Comet NEOWISE? Or when Betelgeuse dimmed in night skies? Those were just a couple of the celestial highlights as we stumbled our way around the sun during these 366 days (it was a leap year, too).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Congress Expected to Approve New Museums Honoring Women and Latinos
description: Long-sought Smithsonian museums dedicated to the contributions of these two groups made it into the $2.3-trillion year-end spending bill. A vote is imminent in both the Senate and the House.
content: After decades-long campaigns, a National Museum of the American Latino and a national museum of women’s history are finally on their way to becoming reality in Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: The Warmth of Ethiopian Honey
description: Maryiza sells four honeys from southwest Ethiopia, and sales help combat deforestation in the region.
content: Assorted raw tree honeys from Ethiopia — prized by a number of chefs for their complex flavors suggesting jasmine, praline, smoke and wheat — are now sold in a tasting set of four from Maryiza. Abalo, Bissana, Grawa and Geteme are the varieties. The honey is gathered in southwest Ethiopia from indigenous trees during flowering season. Sales of the honeys help to support the forests and the local community.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: When the Weather Outside Is Frightful, Here’s How to Stay Warm
description: The right gear, a little planning and practicing for the cold temperatures can help you take celebrations outdoors to avoid Covid-19.
content: How do you stay safe and stay connected with family and friends during a Covid winter?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Pandemic Aid Bolsters Biden and Shows Potential Path for His Agenda in Congress
description: Working together with the president-elect, bipartisan groups in the Senate and House helped push feuding leaders to compromise. It could be a template for the future.
content: Producing it was a torturous, time-consuming affair that did nothing to improve Congress’s reputation for dysfunction. But the agreement on a new pandemic aid package showed the ascendance of moderates as a new force in a divided Senate and validated President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s belief that it is still possible to make deals on Capitol Hill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Styles Desk
title: A Close Reading of Ariana Grande’s Engagement Announcement
description: In an extremely 2020 move, Ms. Grande got quarantine-engaged and announced it in an Instagram photo dump.
content: On Sunday, when Ariana Grande announced her engagement on Instagram, the congratulatory likes and comments flowed in immediately. So did the questions: about her fiancé (a luxury real estate agent named Dalton Gomez), the duration of their relationship (roughly a year, though quarantine timelines should probably be weighted to account for constant contact), the composition of her photography (was she in a car?) and, of course, the ring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Citrus Flavors From Ladurée
description: The French pastry specialist has enlisted the expertise of Jean-François Piège for its holiday offerings.
content: This holiday season, Ladurée has enlisted the Parisian chef Jean-François Piège to create some of its French pastries: macarons, stunning bûches de Noël and, a favorite of mine with a glass of Champagne or just to nibble, his take on a simple loaf cake. Called the Cake, it’s a buttery, citrusy confection festive enough with its tracings of candied peel atop its lemon glaze.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Looking for Light on the Longest Night of the Year
description: Monday is the winter solstice. The next day will be brighter, and the next day will be brighter still.
content: NASHVILLE — Midway through December, in the midst of an unseasonable warm spell, I sent a text to the gang: “Shall we meet on our deck around 6:30?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Disney names a new chairman for its movie division.
description: Disney on Monday cleared up a lingering question at its movie division: Alan Bergman, 54, was named chairman, succeeding Alan F. Horn, 77, a venerable figure in Hollywood who has led Walt Disney Studios since 2012. Mr. Horn will continue to serve as chief creative officer.
content: Disney on Monday cleared up a lingering question at its movie division: Alan Bergman, 54, was named chairman, succeeding Alan F. Horn, 77, a venerable figure in Hollywood who has led Walt Disney Studios since 2012. Mr. Horn will continue to serve as chief creative officer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: 1998 U.S. Embassy Bombing Victims Are Assured Equal Compensation in Deal With Sudan
description: A new congressional agreement largely puts to rest months of furious negotiations over how to help Sudan’s fragile transitional government, which faces lawsuits accusing the country of harboring Al Qaeda.
content: WASHINGTON — Victims of the 1998 bombings of two United States Embassies in East Africa will soon receive up to $485 million in compensation as part of a wide-ranging settlement to remove Sudan from a list of state sponsors of terrorism and, in turn, foster peace with Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Pâtés en Croûte Worthy of a Celebration
description: You might think these gorgeous spreads are from Paris, but they’re from the West Coast shop of the chef Nicolas Delaroque.
content: In response to the pandemic, Nicolas Delaroque has turned his Restaurant Nico in San Francisco into Maison Nico, with the sommelier Paul Einbund. It’s what the French call an épicerie, or gourmet shop, where a selection of fine packaged and freshly made products are sold. The online shop features Mr. Delaroque’s exceptional pâtés en croûte, gorgeous, savory mosaics of meats, including duck, sausage, game, offal and spices, encased in well-burnished pastry. It’s an item worth a holiday celebration, and it can be ordered for shipping nationwide by the portion or whole. Beef cheeks or bouillabaisse-style seafood are layered in aspic and also available for local delivery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Black and Armed
description: The surge in Black gun-buying is a response to America’s failing to create a society where all citizens feel safe.
content: Growing up in rural northern Louisiana, everyone I knew, at least every household, seemed to have guns. Men had guns racked in the back windows of their pickup trucks, and pistols under their seats. Women, like my mother, tucked smaller handguns into their purses.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Delilah
description: With snippets of love, loss and struggle soothed by music, she has become one of American radio’s most popular — and trusted — voices. We decided to give her a call.
content: This episode was hosted and produced by Andy Mills and Bianca Giaever, with help from Leslye Davis. It was edited by Sara Sarasohn, Wendy Dorr and Lisa Tobin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The Year of Telfar
description: A queer Liberian-American designer became the success story of the pandemic. Now he wants to smash the old fashion system to bits.
content: In January 2020, around the time word first began to leak of Covid-19 in China, Telfar Clemens, the queer Liberian-American designer who has been preaching the gospel of inclusivity for 15 years, had a wine-drenched banquet and sleepover for more than 40 of his closest creative collaborators and friends in the Pitti Palace, a former home of the Medicis in Florence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: 2 People-Smugglers Are Convicted of Manslaughter in U.K. Truck Deaths
description: Gheorghe Nica, of Romania, and Eamonn Harrison, of Northern Ireland, were found guilty for the deaths of 39 Vietnamese migrants who were found in a container in southeastern England in 2019.
content: LONDON — Two members of an international people-smuggling gang were convicted of manslaughter on Monday over the deaths of 39 people whose bodies were found in the back of a container truck in southeastern England last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser
title: New York Is Ousting Older Judges to Save Money. They’re Fighting Back.
description: Dozens of judges are being forced to retire to close a pandemic budget gap. They have sued New York State, charging age discrimination.
content: It was last March 11: the day President Trump shut down travel from Europe and Tom Hanks announced he had coronavirus. The mayor of New York was warning people about the risks of leaving home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Zeitlin
title: $1 Trillion, Too Little, Too Late
description: The arbitrary politics of price tags ended up robbing Americans of more help in the new coronavirus relief bill.
content: We now know that millions of unemployed workers won’t be kicked off unemployment insurance (for at least 11 weeks) and will now get $300 every week in addition to their current state benefit; a vast majority of Americans will receive $600 direct payments from the government; and small businesses will have access to a modest new tranche of forgivable government loans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: Should I Have Elective Surgery in the Pandemic?
description: Patients must balance the chance of a life-threatening Covid-19 exposure against the opportunity for relief from a condition that may be painful but is not considered urgent.
content: With the Covid-19 pandemic raging across the country, many people hoping to undergo elective surgery can expect their operations to be on hold indefinitely. Hospitals in many places are at or near bed capacity and facing staff shortages. Even facilities still able to handle operations not considered urgent are likely to experience cancellations when patients themselves, fearing contagion, postpone the procedures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica Newland
title: I’m Haunted by What I Did as a Lawyer in the Trump Justice Department
description: No matter our intentions, lawyers like me were complicit. We owe the country our honesty about what we saw — and should do in the future.
content: I was an attorney at the Justice Department when Donald Trump was elected president. I worked in the Office of Legal Counsel, which is where presidents turn for permission slips that say their executive orders and other contemplated actions are lawful. I joined the department during the Obama administration, as a career attorney whose work was supposed to be independent of politics.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A former big tech insider is helping with antitrust cases against the companies.
description: A former tech industry insider is now playing a key role in the wave of antitrust lawsuits against the giant tech companies.
content: A former tech industry insider is now playing a key role in the wave of antitrust lawsuits against the giant tech companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: Worker Ran Illegal Winery in Alabama Sewage Plant, Sheriff Says
description: The DeKalb County Sheriff’s Office received a tip about an alcohol operation in a wastewater treatment plant in Rainsville, Ala. A 15-year city employee was arrested and charged.
content: A municipal worker in Alabama was arrested after he was caught running an illegal winemaking operation inside a sewage treatment plant, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller and Isabella Kwai
title: For U.K., an Early Taste of Brexit as Borders Are Sealed
description: Battling a new coronavirus variant even as they steel themselves for the looming split with the E.U., Britons are feeling profoundly isolated.
content: LONDON — Christmas plans were canceled. Many flights off the island were stopped. And lawmakers called for cultivating new plots of land to shore up the nation’s food supply, conjuring images of plates full of root vegetables.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: Now That Grandma Has Been Vaccinated, May I Visit Her?
description: The start of a mass coronavirus vaccination campaign at U.S. nursing homes has brought hope to many families. But it may be a while before restrictions loosen. Here are answers to common questions.
content: A watershed moment has arrived for many families: This week health care workers from CVS and Walgreens, under contract from the federal government, will fan out to nursing homes across the country to begin vaccinating residents against the coronavirus. The shots not only will help protect the nation’s elderly and infirm — and the staff who care for them — but they raise the prospect of ending the devastating isolation many residents have felt for months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: Climate Change Legislation Included in Coronavirus Relief Deal
description: The legislation calls for cutting the use of powerful planet-warming chemicals common in air-conditioners and refrigerators.
content: WASHINGTON — In the waning days of the 116th Congress, lawmakers have authorized $35 billion in spending on wind, solar and other clean power sources while curtailing the use of a potent planet-warming chemical used in air-conditioners and refrigerators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: It’s Finally Here. But Is It Enough?
description: Congress finally reached a stimulus deal. Some worry it’s too little, too late.
content: Lawmakers finally struck a $900 billion stimulus compromise yesterday, after months of warnings from economists, corporate leaders and the Fed that the U.S. economy needed additional help. The questions now are whether it’s enough, and who will benefit the most.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Parts of Asia and Europe bar travelers from Britain.
content: Countries across Asia and Europe are racing to bar travelers from Britain, as the U.K. struggles to contain an outbreak of what officials said was a more contagious variant of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: Tested Again, the Chiefs Flex Their Survival Skills
description: Kansas City (13-1) has come back in four of its last six games, and while the Chiefs do not seem invincible, they hardly seem beatable.
content: To an exclusive cohort in the N.F.L., the regular season serves as a preamble, offering those powerful teams 16 opportunities to tinker, learn and adapt. What might work in September might not in January, when the playoffs beckon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: Relief Deal Would Give Small Businesses a Shot at a Second Loan
description: The stimulus package being negotiated in Washington includes $285 billion for a renewed Paycheck Protection Program.
content: Federal lawmakers have agreed to revive the signature small-business relief effort established last spring, committing $285 billion for additional loans under the Paycheck Protection Program and allowing particularly hard-hit companies to get a second loan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: A new variant in Britain has prompted travel bans across the world.
content: This weekend, Britain imposed a wholesale lockdown on London and most of the country’s southeast, citing fears about a new strain of the coronavirus, which officials say is more contagious..
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Rosendo and Rogelio Mendoza, Twins and Texas Welders, Die at 56
description: The Mendoza brothers, identical twins who worked together, died of complications of Covid-19 on the same day.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold
title: She Called Police Over a Neo-Nazi Threat. But the Neo-Nazis Were Inside the Police.
description: Death threats linked to police computers and the discovery of far-right chat groups in police departments across Germany have fed concerns about far-right infiltration.
content: FRANKFURT — Traveling for work and far from home, Seda Basay-Yildiz received a chilling fax at her hotel: “You filthy Turkish sow,” it read. “We will slaughter your daughter.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: Who Takes the Eurostar? Almost No One, as the Pandemic Fuels a Rail Crisis
description: A plunge in ridership at the international high-speed train mirrors wider troubles gripping Europe’s railway industry.
content: PARIS — Earlier this month, David-Alexander Leduc rolled his suitcase down a nearly empty platform at the Gare du Nord train station and scanned his ticket at the turnstile to board the sole Eurostar leaving that day for London.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Your Card Payment Has Been Declined
description: Mastercard’s chief executive oversees $6.5 trillion in transactions. That gives him unique insights into our economic recovery, and power over companies like PornHub.
content: Ajay Banga has spent a decade as chief executive of Mastercard. Last year, he oversaw $6.5 trillion in transactions. That means he knows what we’re spending right now (aggregated and anonymized, of course) and how long it might take to get us out of our current economic funk. It also means Mr. Banga has leverage over virtually any business that relies on credit card payments. For example, following recent reporting from New York Times columnist Nicholas Kristof on the scale of child pornography on PornHub, Mastercard announced that it would terminate payments on that site.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff and Margot Sanger-Katz
title: Surprise Medical Bills Cost Americans Millions. Congress Is Finally Set to Ban Most of Them.
description: Efforts to solve the common consumer problem had been stalled by lobbying pressure and legislative squabbles.
content: After years of being stymied by well-funded interests, Congress has agreed to ban one of the most costly and exasperating practices in medicine: surprise medical bills.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Reopen Schools, and Reform Them
description: Scrapping the high-stakes admission tests for New York’s specialized public high schools is long overdue. They severely disadvantage talented Black and Latino students.
content: The achievement gap in New York’s segregated and unequal schools is poised to become a chasm in the wake of the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Patty Jenkins on ‘Wonder Woman 1984’ and the Future of Theaters
description: Jenkins made history with a lucrative deal to direct this sequel. With Warner Bros. opting to debut it on HBO Max, will she come back for a third film? “We’ll see.”
content: The first “Wonder Woman” movie, directed by Patty Jenkins, was a cinematic game-changer that proved female superheroes were every bit as mighty as men. The new sequel, “Wonder Woman 1984” (due Dec. 25), promises to be a very different kind of game-changer: Once positioned for a billion-dollar box-office gross, it will now debut on the same day both in theaters and on the streaming service HBO Max, a corporate priority for Warner Bros. and its parent company AT&T.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beth Macy
title: If I’d Stayed in My Hometown, Would I Be a Trump Voter?
description: My family lost its shared reality. But some ties still bind.
content: XENIA, OHIO — My 93-year-old mother was dying. It was the Saturday after the election, and the suburban Georgia votes were being tallied. My sister Cookie and I were sitting in Mom’s memory-care unit, the lights dimmed. About the only thing Cookie and I agreed on politically was not to discuss the orange elephant in the room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Noah Weiland
title: Biden receives the coronavirus vaccine.
description: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. received the coronavirus vaccine on live television on Monday at the Christiana Hospital in Newark, Del., sending a message to Americans across the country that the vaccine is safe to take.
content: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. received the coronavirus vaccine on live television on Monday at the Christiana Hospital in Newark, Del., sending a message to Americans across the country that the vaccine is safe to take.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: N.J. Approves $14 Billion in Corporate Tax Breaks in Less Than a Week
description: The incentive package was pushed by Gov. Philip D. Murphy, a progressive Democrat who has railed against similar tax breaks in the past. His allies are not happy.
content: No issue has defined Gov. Philip D. Murphy’s first term in office more than corporate tax incentives. He railed against them as a Democratic candidate for governor and, once elected, initiated an investigation that exposed the program he inherited from his Republican predecessor as a poorly managed boon for politically connected firms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport and Michael Corkery
title: Biden’s Choice of Vilsack for U.S.D.A. Raises Fears for Small Farmers
description: Democrats have struggled to win voters in rural America, and critics say the return of Tom Vilsack, a former agriculture secretary, won’t help.
content: WASHINGTON — Soon after President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. beat President Trump last month, Tom Vilsack, the former agriculture secretary and one of Mr. Biden’s early backers, received an exasperated call from a former aide. Despite the elation over Mr. Biden’s victory, Democrats were again defeated resoundingly in rural America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: After striking a stimulus deal, Congress faces yet another midnight deadline to approve it.
description: After congressional leaders struck a long-sought agreement on a $900 billion pandemic relief package, lawmakers in both chambers on Monday will race to finalize legislative text and send the measure to President Trump’s desk before government funding lapses.
content: After congressional leaders struck a long-sought agreement on a $900 billion pandemic relief package, lawmakers in both chambers on Monday will race to finalize legislative text and send the measure to President Trump’s desk before government funding lapses.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A much-hyped video game has turned into a nightmare for its developer.
description: Since the release of the highly anticipated Cyberpunk 2077 video game on Dec. 10, thousands of gamers have created viral videos featuring a multitude of glitches and bugs — many hilarious — that mar the game and render it virtually unplayable for many users.
content: Since the release of the highly anticipated Cyberpunk 2077 video game on Dec. 10, thousands of gamers have created viral videos featuring a multitude of glitches and bugs — many hilarious — that mar the game and render it virtually unplayable for many users.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Navalny Says Russian Agent Confessed to Plot to Poison Him
description: Aleksei A. Navalny, the Russian opposition leader, published a recording of a phone call in which he says he tricked a security official into exposing the plot.
content: MOSCOW — Aleksei A. Navalny, the Russian opposition leader recovering from a nerve agent attack, has made a career of needling his country’s sprawling security establishment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris and Nicole Perlroth
title: The Mystery of the Disappearing Manuscripts
description: A phishing scam with unclear motive or payoff is targeting authors, agents and editors big and small, baffling the publishing industry.
content: Earlier this month, the book industry website Publishers Marketplace announced that Little, Brown would be publishing “Re-Entry,” a novel by James Hannaham about a transgender woman paroled from a men’s prison. The book would be edited by Ben George.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic and Ethan Hauser
title: Moderna’s vaccine rolls out in the U.S.
description: A week after planes and trucks carried the first Covid-19 vaccine across the United States, inching a weary public toward hope, the second was shipped to sites around the country. The Moderna vaccine, like Pfizer’s, requires two shots, spaced weeks apart. The Food and Drug Administration authorized its emergency use on Friday.
content: A week after planes and trucks carried the first Covid-19 vaccine across the United States, inching a weary public toward hope, the second was shipped to sites around the country. The Moderna vaccine, like Pfizer’s, requires two shots, spaced weeks apart. The Food and Drug Administration authorized its emergency use on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: German White Supremacist Is Sentenced to Life for Synagogue Attack
description: The 28-year-old attacker was convicted of killing two as he tried to storm a synagogue last year. It was described in court as the most despicable act of anti-Semitism in Germany since World War II.
content: MAGDEBURG, Germany — A white supremacist who live-streamed his efforts to blast his way into a synagogue in Germany last year on the holiest day on the Jewish calendar, failing to cause widespread bloodshed only because he could not breach a heavy wooden door, was sentenced on Monday to life in prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Trump Makes Classical Style the Default for Federal Buildings
description: An executive order stopped short of banning modernist architecture, but states that “the preferred architecture” style for new buildings should be classical.
content: President Trump signed an executive order on Monday that establishes classical architecture as the preferred style for new federal buildings but stops short of banning newer designs from consideration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liane Kupferberg Carter
title: How Having a Child With Autism Helps Me Ride Out the Pandemic
description: My life has been filled with uncertainty for a long time, but my son has helped me stay flexible, adjust expectations and persevere.
content: It feels like forever since we took up residence in the United States of Anxiety. As the months drag on, that mix of fear and fortitude I felt at the beginning of the pandemic is giving way to fatigue and frustration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Hudson Valley Brewery Branches Out to Distilling
description: Arrowood Farms in Accord, N.Y., now makes a neutral vodka and a citrusy gin.
content: Arrowood Farms, in Accord, N.Y., caught my eye in 2016 because it was a brewery growing its own hops. The Hudson Valley farm has now grown to include a restaurant, the Apiary, and a distillery, which, like the brewery, is sustainable, using yeast developed from its own honey cultures, locally grown grain and water from a spring on the property. The vodka (80 proof) is quite neutral, mostly about its satiny texture to enjoy well chilled, with just a twist. Caviar would not be a mistake alongside. The gin (90 proof) is dry, but with hints of citrus peel, wildflowers and pine both on nose and palate, making it good martini material if you don’t overdo the vermouth. Their new bourbon (90 proof) aged in Adirondack oak barrels is $35 for a 375-milliliter bottle. The brewery has expanded to produce a range of beers and ales, some seasonal. Come summer, you’ll want Lion’s Tooth, a farmhouse ale brewed with dandelion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘City Hall’ and ‘The Masked Dancer’
description: Frederick Wiseman’s latest documentary airs on PBS. And “The Masked Dancer” debuts on Fox.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Dec. 21-27. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: N.B.A. Western Conference Preview: The Lakers Reloaded
description: Their championship glow still strong, the Lakers are poised to make another run, even as the Warriors bounce back and the Suns ascend.
content: LeBron James was surprised, and a little annoyed, when the N.B.A. unveiled its schedule for the 2020-21 season. He had been hoping for a mid-January start for his title defense with the Los Angeles Lakers. It was wishful thinking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Gorman
title: A Wolf Pup Mummy From the Ancient Arctic
description: Melting permafrost yields secrets of how a 6-week-old wolf puppy lived and died.
content: More than 50,000 years ago, a den in sandy soil collapsed on a wolf pup and killed her, sealing her away from air and moisture so the pup’s body mummified in the cold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arthur Middleton and Justin Brashares
title: More Than Twice the Size of Texas
description: That’s how much land Biden wants to conserve over the next decade. But is it possible?
content: To slow extinctions and climate change, President-elect Joe Biden has embraced a plan to conserve 30 percent of U.S. land and 30 percent of its ocean waters by 2030. It is perhaps the most ambitious commitment to conservation by a U.S. president. How he proceeds will determine whether he unites or further divides Americans in a pivotal decade for the planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: The ‘Red Slime’ Lawsuit That Could Sink Right-Wing Media
description: Voting machine companies threaten “highly dangerous” cases against Fox, Newsmax and OAN, says Floyd Abrams.
content: Antonio Mugica was in Boca Raton when an American presidential election really melted down in 2000, and he watched with shocked fascination as local government officials argued over hanging chads and butterfly ballots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman and Jim Tankersley
title: Stimulus Deal Provides Economic Relief, for Now
description: The aid package will keep millions from losing jobless benefits. But it comes too late to prevent lasting damage to many families and businesses.
content: The congressional agreement on a $900 billion dose of aid to fuel the slowing economic recovery has probably spared millions of Americans from a winter of poverty and kept the country from falling back into recession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang and Javier C. Hernández
title: China Long Avoided Discussing Mental Health. The Pandemic Changed That.
description: The government has deployed extensive resources to address the spike in depression and anxiety. But social stigmas and long-term challenges remain.
content: China’s fight against the coronavirus was mostly over, but Zhang Xiaochun, a doctor in Wuhan, was sinking into depression, convinced she had failed as a daughter and mother. She agonized over her decision to keep working even after her father fell critically ill. She worried about her young daughter, whom she had frequently left alone at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Millions are traveling in the U.S., despite warnings.
description: Airport security checkpoints have handled more than one million passengers a day since Friday.
content: More than a million travelers a day passed through airport security checkpoints on each of the last three days in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard and Ron Lieber
title: The Stimulus Deal: What’s in It for You
description: Lawmakers agreed to issue stimulus payments of $600 and distribute a federal unemployment benefit of $300 for 11 weeks. But that money will take time to start arriving.
content: Another dose of relief is finally on the way for the millions of Americans facing financial distress because of the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Weed
title: How to Manage Performance Evaluations in the Work-From-Home Era
description: A guide for managers in assessing 2020 and looking ahead to next year.
content: A performance review, done well, applauds excellent work, delivers beneficial feedback and inspires a feeling of forward momentum. It’s not easy to pull off in the best of times, and as work-from-home drags on, the task can feel even more challenging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: ‘The Whole City Was Dark’: China Rations Electricity for Millions
description: Warning of coal shortages, officials are trying to curb energy usage by telling residents not to use electric stoves and extinguishing lights on building facades and billboards.
content: In the city of Yiwu in eastern China, the authorities turned off streetlights for several days and ordered factories to open only part-time. In coastal Wenzhou, the government ordered some companies not to heat their offices unless temperatures are close to freezing. In southern Hunan Province, workers have reported climbing dozens of flights of stairs after elevators were shut down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: It’s 2020. Indigenous Team Names in Sports Have to Go.
description: The Chiefs, Braves, Blackhawks and Seminoles need to follow the Cleveland baseball team in dropping their offensive names.
content: Before the Kansas City Chiefs play, Rhonda LeValdo does not feel excitement and joy. She feels outrage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow
title: The Crossword Stumper
description: A look at one of the entries that fooled solvers in last week’s puzzles.
content: A ZEBU is a type of cattle native to South Asia. They are recognizable by the hump on their shoulders, and are renowned for their resistance to heat and insects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: ‘Star Trek’ and Dr. Seuss Mash-Up Not Protected, Court Rules
description: The book, titled “Oh, the Places You’ll Boldly Go!”, hewed too closely to the original to be considered a parody under the “fair use” doctrine, a three-judge federal appeals panel declared.
content: An unauthorized mash-up of the “Star Trek” and Dr. Seuss universes, a book titled “Oh, the Places You’ll Boldly Go!”, is not protected from a copyright infringement claim, a federal appeals court ruled last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon and Sarah Hughes
title: Stimulus, Mutating Virus, Barr: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hailey Fuchs
title: Virus Hits Federal Death Row, Prompting Calls for Delays in Executions
description: At least 14 of the roughly 50 men held in the secure facility at the federal penitentiary in Terre Haute, Ind., have tested positive. Staff members involved in executions have also gotten sick.
content: WASHINGTON — The coronavirus pandemic is sweeping through death row at the federal penitentiary in Terre Haute, Ind., with at least 14 of the roughly 50 men there having tested positive, lawyers for the prisoners and others familiar with their cases said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: Armed protesters angry over virus restrictions try to force their way into the Oregon Statehouse.
description: Armed protesters trying to force their way into Oregon’s State Capitol building on Monday were met by officers in riot gear, as lawmakers gathered for a one-day special session amid growing tension over coronavirus restrictions in the state.
content: Armed protesters trying to force their way into Oregon’s State Capitol building on Monday were met by officers in riot gear, as lawmakers gathered for a one-day special session amid growing tension over coronavirus restrictions in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: A Covid Deal and Pee-wee’s Christmas Card
description: Monday: Applause for the stimulus deal is muted and the governor is back in quarantine, but another vaccine is expected today.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcus Westberg
title: Wintry Scenes From a Swedish Wonderland
description: With his foreign assignments canceled for the year, a photographer refocuses on his homeland — and finds plenty to admire.
content: I consistently give the same advice to aspiring photographers: Wherever home is, that’s where you should begin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Larry Tye
title: M.L.B.’s Records Were Never Real. But the Racism Was. Ask Satchel Paige.
description: Major League Baseball’s plan to formally recognize the Negro leagues exposes the ugliness that has existed all along.
content: Major League Baseball keeps vowing to redress its racist past, but its half-steps only reinforce the elusiveness of that goal, for it and the rest of America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Coronavirus, Stimulus Deal, Rohingya: Your Monday Briefing
description: A worrying mutation of the coronavirus.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt
title: Trump Administration Is Criticized Over Proposal to Split Cyberoperations Leadership
description: As the government grapples with a vast hack, the Pentagon is weighing whether to separate management of the National Security Agency from the United States Cyber Command.
content: WASHINGTON — Confronted with a vast cyberattack believed to have been carried out by Russia, the Trump administration is suddenly reviving an old idea: Strip the general who leads the United States Cyber Command of his second title as the director of the National Security Agency, the country’s largest spy operation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff
title: Mexico Misled Citizens About the Severity of Coronavirus in its Capital
description: The federal government had data that should have prompted an immediate lockdown in early December. Instead, it kept the city open for another two weeks.
content: MEXICO CITY — In early December, the pandemic was roaring back in Mexico City: After declining over the summer, the coronavirus was spreading rapidly, hospitalizations were spiking and ventilators were running low.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Jeffery C. Mays
title: 5 Takeaways From the Mayor’s Race: A Subway Pledge and Police Scrutiny
description: Some New York City candidates vowed to reform the Police Department — or to ride the subway more often than Mayor Bill de Blasio.
content: The Democratic candidates running for mayor of New York City differ on many issues, but they tend to agree on one thing: All aspire to be different from Mayor Bill de Blasio, a Democrat in his second term whose approval rating dropped after his failed run for president last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Moratorium on evictions and foreclosures for F.H.A. loans is extended.
description: The moratorium will now run through Feb. 28. It had been set to expire at the end of the month.
content: The Department of Housing and Urban Development has extend a moratorium on evictions and foreclosures on home mortgages its insures against default, protecting many first-time home buyers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Condiment City
description: Make Tejal Rao’s recipe for salsa macha, a rich chile oil from Veracruz, Mexico.
content: Good morning. One of the few joys of the pandemic lockdown, as Tejal Rao wrote for The Times last week, is the sharp increase in the number of condiments many of us have put in our refrigerators since March. Tejal listed beautiful examples: “Preserved lemons from a neighbor’s tree. Sludgy garlic pickles in a distressingly greasy jar. Tubs of fermented bean pastes and bottles of fish sauce, mouths crusted with salty crystals.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Hamilton
title: Runners’ Races Were Canceled. Their Coaches Filled the Void.
description: Coaches and agents were desperate to help their athletes compete in a year void of competition. So they created a marathon themselves, and watched the list of the fastest American marathons times get rewritten.
content: There were three winners at Sunday’s Marathon Project, a bright spot in an otherwise uncertain year for professional runners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh and Tariq Panja
title: ‘It Doesn’t Work’: Critics of Russia’s Doping Ban Blame the System
description: While athletes and experts lament a court’s reduced punishment for Russia’s doping scandal, the country is already trying to wring a new concession.
content: Clare Egan heard the news last week while resting between training sessions in her hotel room in Hochfilzen, Austria, where she was preparing to compete in a biathlon World Cup event.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: N.B.A. Eastern Conference Preview: Will the Nets Reign Supreme?
description: The Bucks got better, but the Nets with Kyrie Irving and Kevin Durant might be too much for Milwaukee — or any other team in the East — to overcome.
content: Is it already the most wonderful time of year again? With LeBron alley-ooping and referees demanding we be of good cheer? There’ll be dunks used for posting, Kawhi laughs for roasting and trash talking out in the snowwwww.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Jets’ First Win May Cost Them the No. 1 Pick
description: The Jets beat the Los Angeles Rams for their first win of the season, but the victory may give the Jacksonville Jaguars the top pick in the 2021 N.F.L. draft.
content: The Jets did the seemingly unthinkable on Sunday. They won.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Ex-Bloomberg Reporter Who Covered Martin Shkreli Reveals Relationship With Him
description: Christie Smythe helped break the story of Mr. Shkreli’s arrest in 2015. Then she “started to fall for him,” she said, and quit her job at Bloomberg News.
content: “Your Honor, finding love with Martin was a great joy for me.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Barr Sees ‘No Reason’ for Special Counsels for Hunter Biden or the Election
description: The departing attorney general, William P. Barr, again broke with President Trump on his unsupported claims of widespread election fraud and the need to appoint a special counsel to investigate the president-elect’s son.
content: WASHINGTON — Attorney General William P. Barr distanced himself again from President Trump on Monday, saying he saw no reason to appoint special counsels to oversee the Justice Department’s criminal investigation into Hunter Biden, son of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr., or to investigate Mr. Trump’s baseless claims of widespread voter fraud.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word + Quiz: doctrinaire
description: This word has appeared in 19 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario and Emily Cochrane
title: Stimulus Offers $15 Billion in Relief for Struggling Arts Venues
description: The coronavirus relief package that Congressional leaders agreed to this week includes grant money that many small proprietors described as a last hope for survival.
content: For the music venue owners, theater producers and cultural institutions that have suffered through the pandemic with no business, the coronavirus relief package that congressional leaders agreed to this week offers the prospect of aid at last: it includes $15 billion to help them weather a crisis that has closed theaters and silenced halls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Craig
title: Time Isn’t Supposed to Last This Long
description: We’re living in a perpetual present tense. And we are waiting.
content: BETHANY, Conn. — Since March, my family has kept track of time in the changing palette from early spring to fall, a steady transition from gray to gold. A menagerie of birds and beasts, including a fat black bear, have visited, all of them arriving outside our kitchen window for birdseed without the slightest concern about gathering in groups or sharing a meal. We’ve watched them, envious of their audacious freedom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer and Benedict Carey
title: The U.K. Coronavirus Variant: What We Know
description: A newly identified variant of the SARS-CoV-2 virus appears to be more contagious than established ones. Here’s what scientists know.
content: In recent days, the world has watched with curiosity and growing alarm as scientists in the U.K. have described a newly identified variant of the coronavirus that appears to be more contagious than, and genetically distinct from, more established variants. Initial studies of the new variant prompted Prime Minister Boris Johnson to tighten restrictions over Christmas, and spurred officials in the Netherlands, Germany and other European countries to ban travel from the U.K.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Knoll
title: N.H.L. and Players’ Union Reach Framework for 2020-21 Season
description: The season would start Jan. 13 with all seven Canadian teams in one division, but authorities in Canada need to approve plans for teams to practice and play in their markets.
content: Protracted negotiations involving the N.H.L., its board of governors, the players’ union and several moving parts related to municipal, state, provincial and national protocols in two countries culminated Sunday with an agreement for next season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Kilauea Volcano Erupts in Hawaii, Prompting Warning to Stay Inside
description: The civil defense authorities warned people to stay indoors to avoid the fallout of ash carried by the winds.
content: The Kilauea volcano in Hawaii erupted overnight Sunday, prompting the authorities to warn residents to shelter from ash driven by the wind, but there were no immediate concerns about evacuations or threats to life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Levin, Marc Santora, Aurelien Breeden, Tiffany May, Juliana Kim, Raphael Minder and Marie Fazio
title: More nations close their doors to Britain as alarm grows over virus variant.
description: Growing alarm over an outbreak of a more contagious virus variant in Britain prompted mounting concern and travel chaos on Monday as more than 40 nations banned travelers from the country, suspending flights and cutting off trade routes in scenes reminiscent of the frenzied early days of the pandemic.
content: Growing alarm over an outbreak of a more contagious virus variant in Britain prompted mounting concern and travel chaos on Monday as more than 40 nations banned travelers from the country, suspending flights and cutting off trade routes in scenes reminiscent of the frenzied early days of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Poitras
title: I Am Guilty of Violating the Espionage Act
description: The Justice Department is setting a dangerous precedent that threatens reporters — and the truth.
content: I am guilty of violating the Espionage Act, Title 18, U.S. Code Sections 793 and 798. If charged and convicted, I could spend the rest of my life in prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: E.U. Approves Pfizer Vaccine, Setting Stage for High-Stakes Rollout
description: In a landmark collective undertaking, the bloc is poised to start distributing shots to all 27 member nations and their 410 million citizens.
content: BRUSSELS — From Stockholm to Athens and from Lisbon to Warsaw, European Union governments are gearing up to receive a coronavirus vaccine later this week, even as cases keep rising in some parts of the continent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Charting the Virus
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: Let’s check in on the latest coronavirus data this morning, with help from three charts.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: No Warning, No Strings, No Fanfare: A Billionaire Bestows Gifts
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, December 21, 2020.
content: “Usually you don’t have very large philanthropists wandering the landscape looking to drop millions of dollars very quietly into organizations that they care about. The first email literally got stuck in my junk mail.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Taylor
title: Kwanzaa’s Principles and Traditions
description: More about Nguzo Saba, the seven principles of Kwanzaa, as well as some of the symbols of the celebration.
content: During the height of the Black freedom movement in 1960s Los Angeles, Maulana Karenga designed a Black holiday, Kwanzaa, that was modeled after West African harvest festivals on the African continent and used Swahili words and phrases. (Swahili is a lingua franca and mother tongue primarily spoken along the eastern coast of Africa.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Concerns About Coronavirus Variant Cut Off U.K. From Europe
description: Dozens of countries banned air and rail links to Britain, foreshadowing what a “no deal” Brexit could look like in 10 days.
content: LONDON — Britain was all but cut off from the rest of Europe on Monday, with flights and trains banned by some 40 countries and freight deliveries halted at French ports, as its neighbors tried desperately to stop a fast-spreading variant of the coronavirus from leaping across the English Channel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: A ‘Messiah’ for the Multitudes, Freed From History’s Bonds
description: A polyglot, nonsectarian, gender-inclusive film from Canada remakes the Handel classic for today’s world.
content: A gay Chinese-Canadian tenor struts through the streets of Vancouver, joyously proclaiming that “ev’ry valley shall be exalted” as the camera focuses in on his six-inch-high stiletto heels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon and Rick Rojas
title: Senate Candidates Duel in Georgia as G.O.P. Voters’ Anger Persists
description: As the state’s Republican senators rallied with Ivanka Trump, and their Democratic challengers welcomed Kamala Harris, conservative voters were focused on the president’s election loss.
content: MILTON, Ga. — Five Republicans spoke at a rally on Monday in suburban Atlanta, including two state lawmakers, Senators Kelly Loeffler and David Perdue, and Ivanka Trump, the president’s daughter and senior adviser.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green
title: Financial Aid Is Restored for Prisoners in the Education Plan That’s Tucked Into the Stimulus Bill
description: Reversing a ban on Pell grants for prisoners, begun in the 1994 crime bill, is just one of several higher-education equity provisions included in the huge funding bill.
content: WASHINGTON — Tucked into Congress’s voluminous stimulus package are significant changes to higher-education law, including the resumption of federal financial aid to prison inmates that was banned in the 1994 crime bill championed by then-Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $725,000 Homes in California
description: A renovated 1978 house in Rancho Mirage, a 1991 farmhouse with a 10-acre walnut orchard in Corning and a Mediterranean-style home in Oakland.
content: Built in the late 1970s, this house was updated by Thomas Troy, a local builder and designer known for contemporary interpretations of midcentury-modern style. In addition to an interior makeover, the house got a new roof and an outdoor water feature.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman and Katie Benner
title: U.S. Unseals Charges Against New Suspect in 1988 Lockerbie Bombing
description: Attorney General William P. Barr said that investigators had obtained a confession in 2012 from a bomb expert admitting his role in the terrorist attack on a jetliner over Scotland.
content: WASHINGTON — Attorney General William P. Barr on Monday announced criminal charges against a former Libyan intelligence operative accused of building the explosive device that was used in the 1988 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103, one of the deadliest terrorist attacks in United States history, stemming partly to a confession that he gave nearly a decade ago while imprisoned in Libya.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: What Is Something Good That Happened in 2020?
description: What is something positive you discovered about yourself, your family, your community and maybe even your world this year?
content: When you look back at 2020, it might be easy to think of all the challenges. But even though this has been a dark year for so many people, can you think of the good things that happened as well? Did you start any new hobbies, strengthen any relationships, or learn anything about yourself or about the world?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Brennan, Rick Rojas and Sarah Maslin Nir
title: Not an Ideal Process or an Ideal Agreement, but, Finally, a Deal
description: Americans nationwide are glad that Congress, after a painfully prolonged process, has agreed to a stimulus package, however imperfect.
content: BOULDER, Colo. — On the day before Thanksgiving, Dave Query had to close his restaurant for good. For some 26 years, Zolo Grill had been a popular eatery in Boulder offering Southwestern fare. But the slowdown in business, he said, and the cost of complying with state and county safety protocols became too much.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: The Hall of Fame Tries to Contextualize Baseball’s Racist Past
description: Rather than remove the plaques of its most problematic inductees, the Baseball Hall of Fame is hoping to explain them.
content: A plaque at the Baseball Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, N.Y., confers a kind of halo to each member. The gallery feels like a chapel, and the Hall of Famers are the saints. A few gilded sentences summarize the reasons to honor each one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kimmelman
title: Take a Walking Tour of New York
description: Months ago, our architecture critic invited a few people to suggest modest strolls around places meaningful to them. Here’s where they went.
content: Months ago, our architecture critic invited a few people to suggest modest strolls around places meaningful to them. Here’s where they went.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Weiyi Cai and Ford Fessenden
title: Immigrant Neighborhoods Shifted Red as the Country Chose Blue
description: These maps show how areas with Latino and Asian residents shifted the vote in a way that may scramble the future of electoral politics, according to a New York Times analysis of 28,000 precincts.
content: These maps show how areas with Latino and Asian residents shifted the vote in a way that may scramble the future of electoral politics, according to a New York Times analysis of 28,000 precincts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Renard
title: What to Watch: Sci-Fi Movies Led by Women
description: Aliens aren't all these heroes have to contend with. Check out these films with women at the forefront.
content: Aliens aren't all these heroes have to contend with. Check out these films with women at the forefront.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Videos by Ben Proudfoot
title: Cause of Life
description: The more than 300,000 people we lost to the pandemic in 2020 form a portrait of America. For this series of short films, we asked five people to celebrate the life of someone close to them.
content: The more than 300,000 people we lost to the pandemic in 2020 form a portrait of America. For this series of short films, we asked five people to celebrate the life of someone close to them.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $725,000 in California
description: A renovated 1978 house in Rancho Mirage, a 1991 farmhouse with a 10-acre walnut orchard in Corning and a Mediterranean-style home in Oakland.
content: A renovated 1978 house in Rancho Mirage, a 1991 farmhouse with a 10-acre walnut orchard in Corning and a Mediterranean-style home in Oakland.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Videos Show Kilauea Volcano Eruption in Hawaii

author: By Reggie Ugwu, Alexis Soloski, Wesley Morris and Jenna Wortham
title: The Best New Podcasts of 2020
description: Some of this tumultuous year’s most absorbing programming — whether escapist or heartbreaking — could be found in these shows.
content: Every so often the C.I.A. oversees an absolutely deranged project: spy cats, mind control experiments, a booby-trapped conch shell. So the idea that the agency wrote a popular heavy metal song, one that helped thaw the Cold War? Maybe not so crazy. In this eight-episode audio documentary, soft power meets power ballad. The New Yorker writer Patrick Radden Keefe investigates an irresistible rumor — that the C.I.A. composed the Scorpions’ 1990 glasnost-positive anthem, “Wind of Change.” On a shaggy dog international tour, Keefe interviews ex-spies, shadowy music industry figures and the Scorpions’ frontman, Klaus Meine. But this is ultimately a podcast about a conspiracy theory and, as with most conspiracy theories, the solid evidence is thinner than a vinyl pressing. Still, Keefe’s keen reporting and obvious excitement keep your earbuds in, even into the two bonus episodes. ALEXIS SOLOSKI
source.name: The New York Times
